keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up.'
Although Cagle was not armed at the time of arrest, police found an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle outside the airport.

Cagle faces multiple state and federal charges, including terroristic threats, attempted aggravated assaults, possession of a firearm during a felony, and being a convicted felon in possession of a firearm.
The incident occurred at one of the world’s busiest airports, Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, which serves over 108 million passengers annually and is the busiest in the world.
Cagle had a prior conviction for marijuana possession over 20 years ago, which contributed to the federal charge of being a convicted felon in possession of a firearm.
His family alerted Cartersville police that he was armed and on his way to the airport, prompting inter-agency coordination with Atlanta Police.
The FBI is assisting in the investigation due to the potential for mass harm at a high-traffic international hub.
Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem both commented on the incident, emphasizing that the threat was averted due to early intervention and public vigilance.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up.' Though he was not armed at the time of arrest, police discovered an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle. Cagle faces multiple state and federal charges, including terroristic threats, attempted aggravated assaults, and being a convicted felon in possession of a firearm. Authorities credit the incident’s averted outcome to early family reporting and inter-agency coordination. The event occurred at one of the world’s busiest airports, highlighting vulnerabilities in public safety at high-traffic transit locations. The FBI and federal prosecutors are involved, and Cagle’s prior marijuana conviction adds to the legal complexity. The incident underscores the importance of community vigilance and law enforcement response in preventing mass violence at critical infrastructure sites.
